elements.content: Three Cd­(II)-based coordination polymers 1–3 with unique structures and topologies have been successfully constructed under solvothermal conditions by use of a newly designed N-containing rigid triangular ligand tris­(4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (TTPA-4), wherein the structural interpenetration can be modulated by aromatic dicarboxylate coligands including thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (TDA) and terephthalic acid (TPA). Without using coligands, a noninterpenetrating porous 3-D network of 1 with nia topology was obtained. With the aid of the V-shaped TDA coligand, a 4-fold interpenetrating 3-D network of 2 resulted that is built from (2,3,7)-connecting (42.6)­(44.6.88.104.124)­(4)2 net. In the presence of the linear TPA auxiliary ligand, an 8-fold interpenetrating 3-D network of 3 was produced that is assembled by 3-connecting uninodal srs net. Particularly, compound 1 displays interesting dual function as the result of its unique structural attributes, which not only shows superb sensitivity for nitroaromatics (NACs) with phenolic group but also impressive removal capabilities of toxic Cr2O7 2– oxoanion pollutant from aqueous solution.

elements.content: Three 3-D network coordination polymers of 1−3 based on Cd­(II) and tris­(4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine ligand have been synthesized, structural interpenetration of which can be modulated by aromatic dicarboxylate coligands. Among 1−3, 1 not only shows superb sensitivity for nitroaromatics (NACs) with phenolic group but also impressive removal capabilities of toxic Cr2O7 2− oxoanion pollutant from aqueous solution.

Among 1-3, 1 not only shows superb sensitivity for nitroaromatics (NACs) with phenolic group but also impressive removal capabilities of toxic Cr2O7 2- oxoanion pollutant from aqueous solution.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is of great current interest not only due to their charming structures and topologies but also their diversified structure-based functions such as gas storage and separation, sensing, catalysis, drug delivery, and so forth. Constructed by infinite metal–ligand backbones held together through coordination bonds, the inorganic–organic hybrid nature of MOFs permits their structure and function to be finely tuned by judicious combination of metal ions with predesigned ligands under suitable conditions. Structural interpenetration is a common phenomena frequently encountered in the design of MOFs, which may occur only in the case that the pore space of an individual network is large enough to incorporate an additional net. In order to control the degree of interpenetration, various strategies have been explored that include changing the concentration of reactants, the length of organic linkers, the introduction of bulky or pendant groups, and template-directed control methods. Nonetheless, it remains a daunting task for chemists to manipulate structural interpenetration in a controllable manner given that a lot of factors can influence the final assembly output such as solvents, coordination geometry of metal center, the structural characteristics of organic linker, and the nature of the used coligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is of great current interest not only due to their charming structures and topologies but also their diversified structure-based functions such as gas storage and separation, sensing, catalysis, drug delivery, and so forth. Constructed by infinite metal-ligand backbones held together through coordination bonds, the inorganic-organic hybrid nature of MOFs permits their structure and function to be finely tuned by judicious combination of metal ions with predesigned ligands under suitable conditions. Structural interpenetration is a common phenomena frequently encountered in the design of MOFs, which may occur only in the case that the pore space of an individual network is large enough to incorporate an additional net. In order to control the degree of interpenetration, various strategies have been explored that include changing the concentration of reactants, the length of organic linkers, the introduction of bulky or pendant groups, and template-directed control methods. Nonetheless, it remains a daunting task for chemists to manipulate structural interpenetration in a controllable manner given that a lot of factors can influence the final assembly output such as solvents, coordination geometry of metal center, the structural characteristics of organic linker, and the nature of the used coligands.

elements.content: 1,2,4-Triazole and its derivatives, that combine the coordination geometry of both pyrazole and imidazole, have been extensively employed as organic building blocks in the field of crystal engineering largely owing to their coordination diversities. If the N4 site is blocked by substitution, there are only two simple coordination modes that can be foreseen in 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole (4s-TAZ) unit, either N1­(or N2)-monodentate or N1,N2-didentate bridging. Despite its coordination simplicity in a single 4s-TAZ unit, multifarious coordination fashions can yet be envisaged when one organic ligand incorporates two or more such structural units, among which those comprising more than two 4s-TAZ units remain scarce as far as we know.

If the N4 site is blocked by substitution, there are only two simple coordination modes that can be foreseen in 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole (4s-TAZ) unit, either N1(or N2)-monodentate or N1,N2-didentate bridging. Despite its coordination simplicity in a single 4s-TAZ unit, multifarious coordination fashions can yet be envisaged when one organic ligand incorporates two or more such structural units, among which those comprising more than two 4s-TAZ units remain scarce as far as we know.

elements.content: Herein we have designed and synthesized a new N-containing rigid triangular ligand, namely, TTPA-4 (tris­(4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine), that integrates three 4s-TAZ units around a triphenylamine center. Prior to our report, several N-donor ligands based on triphenylamine, such as tri­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine (TIPA), tri­(4-pyridylphenyl)­amine (TPPA), and tris­(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine (TTPA), have enjoyed great popularity for construction of various coordination polymers (). It is worthwhile to note that TTPA-4 in our report is different from the reported TTPA ligand that features covalent linkage between N4 atom of 1,2,4-triazole (instead of N1 atom in TTPA) and triphenylamine, thus allowing for unique N1,N2-bridging mode. Furthermore, the strong σ donor properties of 4s-TAZ unit enable TTPA-4 an effective and strongly coordinating linker that ensures the MOFs robustness. Unlike negatively charged carboxylate ligands, neutral TTPA-4 ligand can be potentially used to construct cationic MOFs with fascinating anion-exchange functions. Apart from the above structural attributes, the central triphenyamine unit in TTPA-4 has evolved into an integral organic component (e.g., TCA = 4,4′,4″-tricarboxytriphenylamine) in MOF-based luminescence sensor for nitroaromatics (NACs) explosive detection as the consequence of its intrinsic electron-rich and luminescence properties. In this work, solvothermal reaction of TTPA-4 with Cd­(NO3)2 resulted in a noninterpenetrating three-dimensional (3-D) porous cationic network, {[Cd­(TTPA-4)]­(NO3)2·3.0H2O·3.5CH3OH} n (1). By contrast, 4-fold and 8-fold interpenetrating networks, viz. {[Cd­(TTPA-4)0.5(TDA)]} n (2) and {[Cd3(TTPA-4) (TPA)3(H2O)3]·5.0H2O} n (3), were isolated with the aid of thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (TDA) and terephthalic acid (TPA), respectively. Interestingly, compound 1 exhibits structure-related dual function, which can not only detect NACs containing phenolic group with superb sensitivity but also efficiently remove Cr2O7 2– oxoanion pollutant from water.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. The synthetic details of TTPA-4 ligand are presented in the Supporting Information. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a CHN-O-Rapid analyzer or an Elementar Vario MICRO analyzer. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrophotometer. The fluorescent spectra were collected on a Horiba FluoroMax 4 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a TA Instruments SDT-Q600 simultaneous DTA-TGA under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on Siemens Bruker D5000 X-ray Powder Diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. The synthetic details of TTPA-4 ligand are presented in the Supporting Information. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a CHN-O-Rapid analyzer or an Elementar Vario MICRO analyzer. UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrophotometer. The fluorescent spectra were collected on a Horiba FluoroMax 4 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a TA Instruments SDT-Q600 simultaneous DTA-TGA under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on Siemens Bruker D5000 X-ray Powder Diffractometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (18.5 mg, 0.06 mmol) and TTPA-4 (13.4 mg, 0.03 mmol) were dissolved in 5 mL of H2O/MeOH (V/V = 1/1) and sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL). The mixture was heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Upon being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, light brown crystals of 1 were collected in 60% yield (based on TTPA-4 ligand). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3414(s), 3079­(m), 1612­(m), 1540(s), 1516(s), 1383­(vs), 1286­(w), 1242­(m), 1103­(w), 1047­(w), 1008­(w), 834­(w), 656­(w), 543­(m), 446­(w). elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data for 1–3 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2014 crystallographic software package. For 1, the disordered atoms (C1, C2, C3, and C4) were refined using C atoms split over two sites with a total occupancy of 1. All the hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Free nitrate anions in 1 and guest solvent molecules (1, MeOH and H2O; 3, H2O) are severely disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. Contributions to scattering due to these molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; structures were then refined again using the data generated. Numbers of solvent molecules in 1 and 3 were obtained by combination of elemental and TGA analyses. The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1–3 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallographic data for 1-3 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-2014 crystallographic software package. For 1, the disordered atoms (C1, C2, C3, and C4) were refined using C atoms split over two sites with a total occupancy of 1. All the hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Free nitrate anions in 1 and guest solvent molecules (1, MeOH and H2O; 3, H2O) are severely disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. Contributions to scattering due to these molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; structures were then refined again using the data generated. Numbers of solvent molecules in 1 and 3 were obtained by combination of elemental and TGA analyses. The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1-3 are summarized in .

In a typical experimental setup, finely ground crystalline sample of 1 (14 mg) was added into MeOH (50 mL) followed by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min, and then sampling 3 mL of stable emulsions for measurement at λex = 347 nm. Then, at room temperature different NACs in MeOH solution were added into the emulsion of 1 for the luminescence detection (2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 3.5 × 10–4 mol/L; 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2.1 × 10–4 mol/L; p-nitrophenol (PNP), 8 × 10–4 mol/L; 2,4-DNT, 2.0 × 10–2 mol/L; nitrotoluene (NT), 2 × 10–2 mol/L; m-dinitrobenzen (m-DNB), 2.0 × 10–2 mol/L; nitrobenzene (NB), 2 × 10–1 mol/L). After each addition, the fluorescence of the suspension was monitored.

elements.content: Bulk crystals of 1 were dipped in aqueous solutions of K2Cr2O7 (2 × 10–4 mol/L, 3 mL) at room temperature and the adsorption of Cr2O7 2– was determined using a UV–vis spectrometer at specified reaction time. The Cr2O7 2– absorbed crystals, namely, 1-Cr2O7, were filtered, water-washed, and air-dried before FT-IR spectroscopy characterization.
elements.clean_text:
Anion-Exchange Experiment

Bulk crystals of 1 were dipped in aqueous solutions of K2Cr2O7 (2 × 10-4 mol/L, 3 mL) at room temperature and the adsorption of Cr2O7 2- was determined using a UV-vis spectrometer at specified reaction time. The Cr2O7 2- absorbed crystals, namely, 1-Cr2O7, were filtered, water-washed, and air-dried before FT-IR spectroscopy characterization.

elements.content: To evaluate the maximal uptake of Cr2O7 2–, five parallel absorption experiments were conducted as follows: at room temperature crystal powder of 1 (15 mg) was added into 50 mL of K2Cr2O7 aqueous solution (15, 25, 40, 50, and 60 mg/L) and stirred for 72 h. The adsorbed amount of Cr2O7 2– was calculated using the mass balance according to : Q e = ( C 0 − C e ) V M where Q e (mg/g) is the equilibrium adsorbed amount; C 0 and C e (mg/L) are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of solution; V (L) is the volume of solution; and M (g) is the mass of 1.

The adsorbed amount of Cr2O7 2- was calculated using the mass balance according to : 1      Q   e   =    (   C   0   -   C   e   )  V   M     where Q e (mg/g) is the equilibrium adsorbed amount; C 0 and C e (mg/L) are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of solution; V (L) is the volume of solution; and M (g) is the mass of 1.

elements.content: Since TTPA-4 ligand can only be dissolved into DMF or MeOH, solvothermal reactions of TTPA-4 with Cd­(NO3)2 were carried out either in MeOH/H2O or DMF/H2O mixed solvent, leading to different coordination structures of 1–3 as confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction (vide infra). In the absence of aromatic carboxylate coligands, a 3-D porous coordination network of 1 was obtained, whereas a 4-fold interpenetrating network of 2 and an 8-fold interpenetrating network of 3 were resulted with the aid of TDA and TPA coligands, respectively. FT-IR spectra of 1 manifests a marked stretching vibration band at 1383 cm–1 characteristic of NO3 – anion, whereas it is invisible in 2 and 3, suggesting the NO3 – anions in 2 and 3 were completely replaced by negatively charged aromatic carboxylate coligands (Figure S3.1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Since TTPA-4 ligand can only be dissolved into DMF or MeOH, solvothermal reactions of TTPA-4 with Cd(NO3)2 were carried out either in MeOH/H2O or DMF/H2O mixed solvent, leading to different coordination structures of 1-3 as confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction (vide infra). In the absence of aromatic carboxylate coligands, a 3-D porous coordination network of 1 was obtained, whereas a 4-fold interpenetrating network of 2 and an 8-fold interpenetrating network of 3 were resulted with the aid of TDA and TPA coligands, respectively. FT-IR spectra of 1 manifests a marked stretching vibration band at 1383 cm-1 characteristic of NO3 - anion, whereas it is invisible in 2 and 3, suggesting the NO3 - anions in 2 and 3 were completely replaced by negatively charged aromatic carboxylate coligands (Figure S3.1).

elements.content: Compound 1 belongs to a hexagonal crystal system with a P63/mmc (#194) space group. As shown in Figure S2.1, the Cd­(II) ion in 1 adopts a perfect [CdN6] octahedral geometry completed by six TTPA-4 ligands as N donors (Cd–N 2.339(3) Å) with N–Cd–N angle of either 90° or 180°, and the TTPA-4 ligand works as a six-connecting linker with each 4s-TAZ unit taking the same N1,N2-bidentate bridging mode. In TTPA-4, the central N atom stays in a sp2-hybridized state as verified by the C–N bond length (1.419 Å) and C–N–C angle of 120°, and three phenyl rings are almost coplanar and perpendicular to the linked 4s-TAZ mean plane. By combination of TTPA-4 ligand in μ6-η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode and Cd­(II) ion of octahedral configuration, a unique [CdN6] n column is formed (Cd···Cd distance, 4.04 Å) with adjacent Cd­(II) ions being triply bridged by three 4s-TAZ units from three TTPA-4 ligands (). Alongside the column, all Cd­(II) ions sit on a trigonal axis with Cd–N–N angle of approximate 125° that is close to the angle (126°) of the exocyclic free donor electron pair of a regular five-membered ring. As a consequence, the triple bridge between two neighboring Cd­(II) ions in 1 are formed without appreciable strain that is a preferred coordination geometry for 4s-TAZ unit. In 1, all [CdN6] n columns are aligned in parallel and spaced by TTPA-4 ligands to give a 3-D network, wherein TTPA-4 ligands are arranged in a face-to-face fashion with a equal separation of 8.08 Å (). In the network of 1, there exists a rhombus channel (16.80 × 10.40 Å in dimension) along c axis wherein disordered free NO3 – anions and solvent molecules are accommodated (a). Topologically, compound 1 can be rationalized as a 3-D (6,6)-connected network with nia topology (point symbol: (412.63)­(49.66)) if viewing Cd­(II) ion and TTPA-4 ligand as 6-connector (b). Using the SQUEEZE function in PLATON, a void accessible volume of 43.9% (excluding NO3 – anions and solvent molecules) was calculated.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (#15). As illustrated in Figure S2.2a, the Cd­(II) ion in 2 is hepta-coordinated by five carboxylate O atoms from three TDA coligands and two N atoms from two TTPA-4 ligands (Cd1–O1 2.448(2) Å, Cd1–O2 2.316(2) Å, Cd1–N1 2.326(3) Å, Cd1–O3A 2.344(2) Å, Cd1–N5 2.383(2) Å, Cd1–O4A 2.427(2) Å, Cd1–O4B 2.458(2) Å). The coordination geometry of Cd­(II) ion might be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid that places N1 and O4 atoms at axial positions (N1–Cd1–O4A, 173.05(9)o). Alternate linkage between TDA coligand in a μ2-η1:η1:η1:η1 (chelating-bridging) coordination fashion and Cd­(II) ions results in a zigzag chain (Cd···Cd distance of 10.47 Å), which is further adhered to another one in parallel through Cd–O coordination (Cd1–O4A 2.427(2) Å) to give a double-chain structure composed of Cd2O2 cluster (Cd···Cd separation of 3.66 Å) (a). Therefore, the whole coordination mode of TDA coligand in 2 is μ2-η1:η1:η1:η2 (Figure S2.2b). All double-chains are extended along the same direction and separated by TTPA-4 ligands, wherein each TTPA-4 ligand connects four Cd­(II) ions from three double-chains with three 4s-TAZ units in two distinct coordination fashions, that is, two in N1-monodentate mode and one in N1,N2-bridging mode (b and Figure S2.2b). Although the central N atom of TTPA-4 ligand in 2 remains in a sp2-hybridized state (average C–N, av. 1.43 Å and C–N–C, av. 120°), three phenyl rings are severely distorted with large dihedral angles (74.16° and 81.90°), and the 4s-TAZ unit is also rotated by 32.21° with respect to its linked phenyl plane. In the 3-D network of 2, all TTPA-4 ligands are arrayed in an eclipsed fashion with a uniform spacing of 19.54 Å, building a rhombus-like channel (16.07 × 11.77 Å in dimension) (b,c). From a topological view, compound 2 exhibits a 3-D (2,3,7)-connecting 3-nodal net evaluated as (42.6)­(44.6.88.104.124)­(4)2 topology if considering Cd­(II) ion as 7-connector (a), TTPA-4 ligand as 3-connector, and TDA anion as a linker. As seen from a single framework of 2, the potential voids are large enough to permit three independent equivalent ones to interpenetrate it, resulting in a 4-fold interpenetrating net (b).

elements.content: Compound 3 belongs to a hexagonal crystal system space group R3c (#161). As depicted in Figure S2.3a, the Cd­(II) ion in 3 is bound by four carboxylate O atoms from two TPA coligands, one N atom from TTPA-4 ligand, and one water molecule. Interestingly, TPA coligands hold Cd­(II) ions together in a chelating-bridging manner to afford a helical chain with a pitch length of 24.27 Å (Figures S2.3b and 5a), and each TTPA-4 ligand through three N1-monodenate 4s-TAZ units joins three Cd­(II) ions from three helical chains propagating along the same direction, leading to a 3-D network (Figures S2.3b and 5a). Different from 1 and 2, TTPA-4 ligand in 3 centered on a sp2-hybridized N atom exhibits a C 3-axial symmetry with the dihedral angles of phenyl-to-phenyl ring and triazole-to-phenyl ring being 75.0° and 9.8°, respectively. In the 3-D network of 3, all TTPA-4 ligands are arranged in an eclipsed fashion with an equal spacing of 24.28 Å, generating 1-D quasi-hexagonal channel (about 24.54 Å of transannular distance) (a,b). Topologically, if treating Cd­(II) ion and TTPA-4 ligand as 3-connector and TPA coligand as a linker, compound 3 can be simplified as 3-D 3-connecting uninodal srs net with a Schläfli symbol of (103) (a). As seen from the single network of 3, the potential void of 3 is so large that it can even allow seven equivalent nets to interpenetrate it, giving an 8-fold interpenetrating network (b).

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1–3 were measured under a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, a weight loss of 13.0% was observed from the room temperature to 104 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd. 13.2%). Its framework remains stable up to 210 °C, from which the decomposition of framework occurs (Figure S3.2). For 2, a plateau region in TGA curve from the 25 to 323 °C was observed, beyond which abrupt weight loss happens due to the framework collapse (Figure S3.3). For 3, the initial weight loss of 7.0% happened from 25 to 233 °C owing to the loss of guest H2O molecules (calcd. 6.4%), and the stability of its framework can be maintained up to 310 °C (Figure S3.4).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1-3 were measured under a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, a weight loss of 13.0% was observed from the room temperature to 104 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd. 13.2%). Its framework remains stable up to 210 °C, from which the decomposition of framework occurs (Figure S3.2). For 2, a plateau region in TGA curve from the 25 to 323 °C was observed, beyond which abrupt weight loss happens due to the framework collapse (Figure S3.3). For 3, the initial weight loss of 7.0% happened from 25 to 233 °C owing to the loss of guest H2O molecules (calcd. 6.4%), and the stability of its framework can be maintained up to 310 °C (Figure S3.4).

elements.content: The phase purities of as-synthesized samples of 1–3 were verified by powder XRD (PXRD) analyses, wherein the experimental PXRD patterns of 1–3 are essentially consistent with the simulated PXRD patterns (Figures S3.5-S3.7).

elements.content: Solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1–3 have been examined at room temperature. As depicted in Figures S3.8–S3.10, compounds 1–3 exhibit stronger emission bands than their respective organic ligands probably because metal-coordination increases the rigidity of the ligand that reduces loss of energy by radiationless decay. Compared to TTPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm), a blue-shift (ca. 8 nm) in the emission (λem = 412 nm, λex = 368 nm) of 1 was observed, which can be safely assigned to the ligand-centered transition. By contrast, compounds 2–3 (2, λem = 483 nm, λex = 397 nm; 3, λem = 500 nm, λex = 387 nm) exhibit large red-shift in emission peaks with respect to both TPPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm) and their corresponding free aromatic acid (TDA in 2, λem = 465 nm, λex = 397 nm; TPA in 3, λem = 424 nm, λex = 387 nm), which might be ascribed to cooperative effects of intraligand as well as ligand-to-ligand charge transition.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of 1-3 

Solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1-3 have been examined at room temperature. As depicted in Figures S3.8-S3.10, compounds 1-3 exhibit stronger emission bands than their respective organic ligands probably because metal-coordination increases the rigidity of the ligand that reduces loss of energy by radiationless decay. Compared to TTPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm), a blue-shift (ca. 8 nm) in the emission (λem = 412 nm, λex = 368 nm) of 1 was observed, which can be safely assigned to the ligand-centered transition. By contrast, compounds 2-3 (2, λem = 483 nm, λex = 397 nm; 3, λem = 500 nm, λex = 387 nm) exhibit large red-shift in emission peaks with respect to both TPPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm) and their corresponding free aromatic acid (TDA in 2, λem = 465 nm, λex = 397 nm; TPA in 3, λem = 424 nm, λex = 387 nm), which might be ascribed to cooperative effects of intraligand as well as ligand-to-ligand charge transition.

elements.content: Encouraged by the great success of metal–TCA coordination polymers as chemical sensor for NACs detection, it is expected that compound 1 can also show good performance for sensing NACs based on its luminescence properties and open framework. As shown in Figure S3.11, the luminescence intensity of 1 closely depends on the solvent, descending in the order of MeOH > DMF > H2O > MeCN ≫ NB. Complete luminescence quenching observed in NB solvent indicates the potential of 1 as luminescence sensor to detect NACs. With these in mind, a series of NACs including TNP, 2,4-DNP, 2,4-DNT, m-DNB, 4-NT, and PNP (Figures S4.1) have been further selected for evaluating sensibility of 1. By virtue of luminescence quenching, it is found that 1 is capable of sensing all above NACs with the quenching efficacy increasing with concentration of NACs ( and S4.2–S4.6).
elements.clean_text:
Sensing NACs Properties of 1 

Encouraged by the great success of metal-TCA coordination polymers as chemical sensor for NACs detection, it is expected that compound 1 can also show good performance for sensing NACs based on its luminescence properties and open framework. As shown in Figure S3.11, the luminescence intensity of 1 closely depends on the solvent, descending in the order of MeOH > DMF > H2O > MeCN ≫ NB. Complete luminescence quenching observed in NB solvent indicates the potential of 1 as luminescence sensor to detect NACs. With these in mind, a series of NACs including TNP, 2,4-DNP, 2,4-DNT, m-DNB, 4-NT, and PNP (Figures S4.1) have been further selected for evaluating sensibility of 1. By virtue of luminescence quenching, it is found that 1 is capable of sensing all above NACs with the quenching efficacy increasing with concentration of NACs ( and S4.2-S4.6).

elements.clean_text: 7  Emission spectra of 1 at different concentrations of (a) NB and (b) TNP.

elements.content: Interestingly, compound 1 displays two disparate luminescence-responsive behaviors toward these NACs. For nitro phenolic aromatics (TNP, 2,4-DNP, and PNP), the intensity of maximum emission of 1 drops gradually with concurrent blue-shift of wavelength when the analyte concentration is increased (b, S4.5, and S4.6). The observed blue-shift toward those nitro phenolic aromatics might be attributed to electrostatic interactions between the basic N sites of 1 and acidic phenolic groups of those nitro phenolic aromatics. The maximum blue-shift is 26 nm for TNP, 25 nm for 2,4-DNP, and 24 nm for PNP (Figure S4.7). For those NACs without phenolic group (m-DNB, NB, PNA, and 4-NT), it is only observed that the intensity of maximum emission of 1 decreased with incremental concentration of NACs but the wavelength remains constant (a, S4.2–S4.4). Such interesting sensing behaviors of 1 might be utilized to differentiate from NACs with and without phenolic group. Upon close inspection on quenching constant (K sv) of each NAC, it reveals that 1 exhibits the superior sensitivity for those nitro phenolic aromatics (TNP, 6.4 × 105 M–1; 2,4-DNP, 6.2 × 105 M–1; PNP, 8.7 × 104 M–1) with limit of detection (LOD) at ppb level (TNP, 72 ppb; 2,4-DNP, 77 ppb; PNP, 510 ppb) (Figures S4.8-S4.11, Table S4.1). To the best of our knowledge, the sensitivity of 1 for these nitro phenolic aromatics is among the highest (Tables S4.2–S4.4). Eventually, it is noteworthy that the postexperiment framework integrity of 1 was well preserved as ascertained by its almost unchanged PXRD pattern compared to that of the pre-experiment samples (Figure S4.13), and it can be repeatedly used for at least five times without significant loss of quenching efficiency (Figure S4.12).

elements.content: Generally, two mechanisms, viz. PET (photoinduced electron transfer) and FRET (fluorescence resonance energy transfer), are responsible for luminescence quenching. To better understand the origin of the superb sensitivity of 1 for those nitro phenolic aromatics, the quenching mechanism was further studied. First, we calculated the energy levels of HOMO and LUMO orbitals for the tested NACs and 1 computed at the B3LYP/SDD (on Cd) and 6-31G* (on H, C, N) level using the Gaussian 09 package of programs (Table S4.5, Figure S4.14). It is found that the LUMO energy level of 1 lies above these tested NACs, which supports the PET mechanism. However, the order of observed quenching efficiency is not fully in accordance with the order of LUMO energies, implicating that the fluorescence quenching is not operative solely via PET mechanism. Second, we compared the emission spectra of 1 and the absorption spectra of all NACs (Figures S4.15 and S4.16). It can be clearly seen that there is a negligible spectra overlap for those NACs without phenolic hydroxyl group (2,4-DNT, m-DNB, and 4-NT). By contrast, a considerable spectra overlap is observed for those nitro phenolic aromatics (TNP, 2,4-DNP, and PNP) with the overlap area following the order of TNP > 2,4-DNP ≈ PNP. Taken together, the luminescence quenching of 1 toward those NACs without phenolic group is obviously caused by PET mechanism, whereas for those NACs with phenolic group it might be resulted from synergistic work of both PET and FRET, which may also account for the higher quenching efficiency for those NACs with phenolic group.

elements.content: As a subclass, cationic MOFs have held great promise for anion receptor/separators with sensitivity, selectivity, and simplicity due to the confinement of substitutable anionic species. In this context, the exploration of cationic MOFs as absorbents for toxic oxoanions (e.g., Cr2O7 2–) has great significance on water pollution remediation since several inorganic pollutants in the form of oxoanions are on the top list of priority pollutants from the Environment Protection Agency (EPA). Nonetheless, the development of cationic MOFs for removal of oxoanions encountered in wastewater streams is still in its infancy. Considering the open and cationic framework of 1, absorption of oxoanion pollutant of Cr2O7 2– based on 1 through anion-exchange was preliminarily investigated (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Properties of 1 

As a subclass, cationic MOFs have held great promise for anion receptor/separators with sensitivity, selectivity, and simplicity due to the confinement of substitutable anionic species. In this context, the exploration of cationic MOFs as absorbents for toxic oxoanions (e.g., Cr2O7 2-) has great significance on water pollution remediation since several inorganic pollutants in the form of oxoanions are on the top list of priority pollutants from the Environment Protection Agency (EPA). Nonetheless, the development of cationic MOFs for removal of oxoanions encountered in wastewater streams is still in its infancy. Considering the open and cationic framework of 1, absorption of oxoanion pollutant of Cr2O7 2- based on 1 through anion-exchange was preliminarily investigated (see ).

elements.content: As shown in a, the UV–vis adsorption band of Cr2O7 2– (375 nm) decreased with the time, indicating that the Cr2O7 2– oxoainions in solution were efficiently trapped by 1 by exchanging with NO3 – anions. The anion-exchange process between Cr2O7 2– and NO3 – was further evidenced by IR spectra, wherein the Cr2O7 2– absorbed sample of 1, 1-Cr2O7 2–, shows evident stretching vibrations of Cr2O7 2– at about 780 and 940 cm–1, and weak vibrations of NO3 – at 1384 cm–1 compared to the pristine sample of 1 (b). Especially, the absorption process of Cr2O7 2– with 1 can be monitored in real time through visual colorimetric change of the Cr2O7 2– solution (from yellow to colorless) (c), concurrent with powder color change of 1 from brown to yellow (Figure S5.1). The maximal exchange capacity of 1 for Cr2O7 2– is calculated to be 137.7 mg/g, which is ranked fourth among the limited MOF-based absorbents (Figure S5.2, Table S5.1). It is worth noting that the structure integrity of 1-Cr2O7 is found to be retained upon Cr2O7 2– absorption since there are no major changes in the PXRD pattern of Cr2O7 2–-absorbed samples (Figure S5.3).

elements.content: Three Cd­(II)-based coordination polymers 1–3 with TTPA-4 ligand have been successfully achieved by solvothermal reactions, of which the structural interpenetration (1, noninterpenetration; 2, 4-fold interpenetration; 3, 8-fold interpenetration) can be modulated by use of aromatic dicarboxylate coligands (V-shaped TDA and linear TPA). Among them, compound 1 possesses a 3-D porous cationic framework integrating triphenylamine chromophore. As for the matter of the unique structure of 1, compound 1 not only shows extraordinary sensing ability for NACs with phenolic group but also remarkable absorption capability for Cr2O7 2– oxoanion.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three Cd(II)-based coordination polymers 1-3 with TTPA-4 ligand have been successfully achieved by solvothermal reactions, of which the structural interpenetration (1, noninterpenetration; 2, 4-fold interpenetration; 3, 8-fold interpenetration) can be modulated by use of aromatic dicarboxylate coligands (V-shaped TDA and linear TPA). Among them, compound 1 possesses a 3-D porous cationic framework integrating triphenylamine chromophore. As for the matter of the unique structure of 1, compound 1 not only shows extraordinary sensing ability for NACs with phenolic group but also remarkable absorption capability for Cr2O7 2- oxoanion.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1–3 were measured under a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, a weight loss of 13.0% was observed from the room temperature to 104 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd. 13.2%). Its framework remains stable up to 210 °C, from which the decomposition of framework occurs (Figure S3.2). For 2, a plateau region in TGA curve from the 25 to 323 °C was observed, beyond which abrupt weight loss happens due to the framework collapse (Figure S3.3). For 3, the initial weight loss of 7.0% happened from 25 to 233 °C owing to the loss of guest H2O molecules (calcd. 6.4%), and the stability of its framework can be maintained up to 310 °C (Figure S3.4).

Luminescence Properties of <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

Solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1–3 have been examined at room temperature. As depicted in Figures S3.8–S3.10, compounds 1–3 exhibit stronger emission bands than their respective organic ligands probably because metal-coordination increases the rigidity of the ligand that reduces loss of energy by radiationless decay. Compared to TTPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm), a blue-shift (ca. 8 nm) in the emission (λem = 412 nm, λex = 368 nm) of 1 was observed, which can be safely assigned to the ligand-centered transition. By contrast, compounds 2–3 (2, λem = 483 nm, λex = 397 nm; 3, λem = 500 nm, λex = 387 nm) exhibit large red-shift in emission peaks with respect to both TPPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm) and their corresponding free aromatic acid (TDA in 2, λem = 465 nm, λex = 397 nm; TPA in 3, λem = 424 nm, λex = 387 nm), which might be ascribed to cooperative effects of intraligand as well as ligand-to-ligand charge transition.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

The thermal stabilities of crystalline samples of 1-3 were measured under a nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, a weight loss of 13.0% was observed from the room temperature to 104 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd. 13.2%). Its framework remains stable up to 210 °C, from which the decomposition of framework occurs (Figure S3.2). For 2, a plateau region in TGA curve from the 25 to 323 °C was observed, beyond which abrupt weight loss happens due to the framework collapse (Figure S3.3). For 3, the initial weight loss of 7.0% happened from 25 to 233 °C owing to the loss of guest H2O molecules (calcd. 6.4%), and the stability of its framework can be maintained up to 310 °C (Figure S3.4).

Luminescence Properties of 1-3 

Solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1-3 have been examined at room temperature. As depicted in Figures S3.8-S3.10, compounds 1-3 exhibit stronger emission bands than their respective organic ligands probably because metal-coordination increases the rigidity of the ligand that reduces loss of energy by radiationless decay. Compared to TTPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm), a blue-shift (ca. 8 nm) in the emission (λem = 412 nm, λex = 368 nm) of 1 was observed, which can be safely assigned to the ligand-centered transition. By contrast, compounds 2-3 (2, λem = 483 nm, λex = 397 nm; 3, λem = 500 nm, λex = 387 nm) exhibit large red-shift in emission peaks with respect to both TPPA-4 ligand (λem = 420 nm, λex = 365 nm) and their corresponding free aromatic acid (TDA in 2, λem = 465 nm, λex = 397 nm; TPA in 3, λem = 424 nm, λex = 387 nm), which might be ascribed to cooperative effects of intraligand as well as ligand-to-ligand charge transition.
